dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A river flows, not far from a small house in the Sussex countryside. SUPERIMPOSE: SUSSEX, ENGLAND. 1941. It is the 28th of March, a desolate, gray morning, as a woman of 59, very thin, in a huge overcoat with a fur collar, comes out of the house and hurries across the lawn. The edge of the lawn turns into a grassy, open field as she carries on her way, moving quickly, determinedly towards her destination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman reaches an embankment and has to clamber down to a brackish, mud-brown River Ouse. Her elegant, unsuitable shoes stick in the mud. The woman is seen more closely -- her face pale, fine, gaunt. As soon as she gets to the river's edge she looks round for a suitable stone. She sees one lying on the ground, the size and shape of a pig's skull. She picks it up and crams it a little clumsily into the pocket of her coat. Then VIRGINIA WOOLF turns and without taking off her shoes begins to wade out into the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEONARD WOOLF is coming in from the garden on the other side of the house. At this point, he is 61. He has muddy corduroys and a pullover, the very picture of the aging intellectual -- austere, ascetic with a fine forehead and glasses. He comes distractedly into a small hallway at the back of the house and starts taking off his Wellington boots, unaware of anything wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two blue envelopes are propped up on the mantelpiece. In handwriting, the single word "Leonard" is on one; the single word "Vanessa" is on the other. LEONARD'S hand reaches to lift his envelope, leaving the other where it is. He stands, fearful. The sitting room of the house is bohemian, casual, artistic, attractive. A YOUNG MAID comes into the room, unaware of the drama that is about to unfold.

dialogues.speaker: MAID
dialogues.text: Are you ready for lunch, sir? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Not quite. Not just at the moment. The MAID goes out. LEONARD, still in his gardening clothes, is tense as he opens the envelope. He unfolds two blue pages. VIRGINIA WOOLF'S voice is hard as she reads the letter.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dearest, I feel certain that I am going mad again. I feel we can't go through another of these terrible times. And I shan't recover this time. I begin to hear voices and can't concentrate. So I am doing what seems the best thing to do. LEONARD looks up, alarmed, beginning to panic.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You have given me the greatest possible happiness. You have been in every way all that anyone could be. I know that I am spoiling your life, that without me you could work. And you will, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEONARD runs back down to pull on his Wellington boots, then runs out of the back room. He comes out of the house and moves rapidly down the lawn. Terrified, he begins to run as the river comes in sight. Meanwhile:

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You see, I can't write this properly. I want to say is that I owe all the happiness of my life to you. You have been entirely patient with me and incredibly good. Everything has gone from me but the certainty of your goodness. I can't go on spoiling your life any longer. I don't think two people could have been happier than we have been. LEONARD has reached the edge of the river. He sees a woman's footprints in the mud. He looks out across its empty, flowing surface.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Virginia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At once the image of VIRGINIA WOOLF'S body, face down, swirling fantastically like a Catherine wheel, back on the surface of the water and carried along by the current. Her hair is unloosed, her coat has billowed out. Her body swirls, moving fast downstream, wildly festooned like Ophelia, then comes to rest against an underwater pillar and curls up like a baby as the water catches the corpse against the stone. It is caught against the stanchion of a bridge. Over the bridge, in convoy, a line of Army trucks is passing, loaded with soldiers in transit. The convoy passes over, ignorant of the corpse beneath the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CREDIT SEQUENCE. Now a delivery truck moves down a suburban street. SUPERIMPOSE: LOS ANGELES. 1951. The CREDITS BEGIN. It is only just past dawn as the truck passes a car coming from the opposite direction. The car approaches a one-level, small detached house, which sits, secure, confident, a family image of post-war America. The car draws up in the drive, and from it gets out DAN BROWN, a sturdy, handsome American, just turning 30. He wears suit trousers and a white open-neck shirt, and he is carrying a bunch of white roses. He lets himself in through the front door, and moves, roses in hand, along past the sitting room with its pastel shades and low, sparse furniture into the kitchen. As he reaches for a vase, he looks towards the door of a nearly-darkened bedroom which is open at the back of the house. A few rays of light from the window help to pick out shapes. In the bedroom LAURA BROWN, a few years older than DAN, is lying asleep in the bed. She is small, angular and fragile. She turns a moment in her sleep.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: A younger LEONARD WOOLF, only 43, is walking past the church, carrying a newspaper and a pile of envelopes and packages he has collected. This suburban quarter, a half an hour away from London, is rich with flowers, lawns, trees. In the other direction come the morning COMMUTERS, dark-coated men, on their way to the station to work. Beside the church is a big gray-stoned house, its great face unmoving in the dawn.  10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEONARD WOOLF opens the door of the house and goes into the hall, which is lined with paintings. He puts down the packages and paper and looks up in time to see a man in his 60s, obviously a DOCTOR -- he carries a doctor's bag and is in a dark coat -- coming down the stairs, heading to have a word with him.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Ah, Doctor. Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Mr. Woolf. No worse, I think. The main thing is to keep her where she is, keep her calm.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Mmm. Friday then?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Friday. Their conversation is left behind. Upstairs, on the first floor, beyond the banisters of an open gallery, is the room the DOCTOR has come out of. Inside the bedroom, a woman is alone. She is lying chastely, blinds down at the windows. She is the younger VIRGINIA WOOLF, now only 41. She is staring up at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: A SUBWAY TRAIN RATTLES violently PAST and a lone WOMAN is left standing on the platform. At street level, the sun is just about to rise down West 10th, one of the leafiest and most pleasant streets in the Village. The woman, SALLY LESTER, is walking quickly down the dawn street, returning home. She is tall, dark, dynamic, in her late 30s, wearing a leather jacket and jeans. She approaches a high red-brick terraced house, goes up the steps and lets herself in through its white-painted front door. SALLY goes up to the first-floor apartment, which she also unlocks. SALLY walks straight through the living room of quiet, Bloomsbury-bourgeois homeliness -- terracotta and pine, clay post, ceramics, plants and massive numbers of books. She goes down a corridor into a warm-colored bedroom, light beginning to beat now against large blinds. SALLY sheds clothes as she goes, taking off her leather jacket and jeans, stripping down to a T-shirt and knickers. She gets into the bed, does nothing to wake the apparently sleeping figure beside her. CLARISSA VAUGHAN is short of 50, tall, splendid beside the smaller SALLY. CLARISSA does not react visibly, but a moment after SALLY closes her eyes, CLARISSA opens hers.  11 12

dialogues.speaker: ALL OF THE ABOVE
dialogues.text: 2001, 1951 and 1923. In MONTAGE, DAN BROWN stands in the bedroom in front of the mirror, tying his tie. CLARISSA throws back the sheet from the bed and gets up. She comes into the small bathroom in her white night gown, ties her hair back behind her head. LAURA, awake now, reaches for a book which is lying at the side of her bed. As her hand reaches for it, the title is clearly seen: Mrs. Dalloway. VIRGINIA sits alone in her bedroom in her dressing-gown, looking at herself in the mirror, then lifts her fingers to adjust her hair. Water pours onto CLARISSA'S face in the shower as she reaches her naked arm out in front of her to grope for the tap, invisible in steam. DAN sets out the breakfast things at the kitchen table for three people,’ then goes and spoons Nescafe for himself into a mug. He pours on hot water. CLARISSA, in a robe, goes to fill her percolator from a kitchen sink which is full of live crabs, in water. VIRGINIA completes dressing, checks herself neatly in the mirror, walks down the corridor and stands for a moment at the top of the stairs, readying herself. CLARISSA comes into her living room, stands in the middle with her remote control and adjusts the lighting, then turns ON a CLASSICAL RADIO STATION. LAURA arranges the pillows to enjoy a luxurious few moments of reading. She turns to listen for the sound of her husband in the kitchen. In succession, the three women, suspended: VIRGINIA, pausing, CLARISSA looking around satisfied with the environment she has created, LAURA listening. Then one thing disturbs CLARISSA: a bunch of sorry-looking dead flowers in the corner of the room. She shakes her head in irritation. DAN brings his roses from the sink and puts the vase on the kitchen table. As he does so, another vase is put down by a MAID'S hands, this time with a bunch of blue cornflowers. As it goes down, echoing the identical motion from 28 years later, the CREDITS END.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vase of cornflowers is seen to be on a table in the open hall of Hogarth House. LEONARD WOOLF is sitting eating toast, drinking coffee, and already proof-reading a manuscript. He looks up at the sound of VIRGINIA appearing from upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Good morning, Leonard.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Good morning, Virginia. How was your sleep? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Uneventful.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: The headaches?

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: No. No headaches.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: The doctor seemed pleased. VIRGINIA helps herself to tea from the table and nods at the mail.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: That's all from this morning?

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Yes. This young man has submitted his manuscript. I've found three errors of fact and two spelling mistakes and I'm not yet on page four. LEONARD is watching her all the time and sees that she is not planning to sit down.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Have you had breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Liar. LEONARD'S tone is casual. He has the quiet, tactful manner of a good nurse.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Virginia, it is not my insistence. It's the wish of your doctors. VIRGINIA just looks at him, not answering.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: I'm going to send Nelly up with a bun and some fruit. Again, VIRGINIA looks at LEONARD, disobediently. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Very well, then. Lunch. A proper lunch. Husband and wife sitting down to soup, pudding and all. By force, if necessary.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Leonard, I believe I may have a first sentence. LEONARD looks her in the eye, knowing how stubborn she is.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Work, then. But then you must eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIRGINIA goes into her plain, serene study and sits down, picking up a board on which she writes. There is an inkwell, a fountain pen. She lights a cigarette. Then, charged with quiet excitement, she opens a clean notebook. The blank page. Then a feeling of pleasure appears on her face in the hushed room. Before writing she tries her sentence out loud.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Mrs. Dalloway said she would buy the flowers herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAURA is lying in the bed, luxuriating in a moment of being alone. She reaches for the copy of Mrs. Dalloway beside her bed and she opens it. She smiles in anticipated pleasure. She speaks out loud.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: 'Mrs. Dalloway said she would buy the flowers herself.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARISSA is standing in the middle of the living room, frowning, as if wondering what she should do. Then she calls out to SALLY, unseen in the other room.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Sally! I think I'll buy the flowers myself.  16 17

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SALLY, still lying in bed, blearily reacts to what she has heard.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: What? What flowers? And then she remembers what day it is. SALLY starts to get out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Oh shit, I'd forgotten... SALLY falls back on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 5-year-old boy is watching as cereal is poured into a bowl. LAURA and DAN'S son, RICHIE, is sitting at the table as DAN prepares his breakfast. RICHIE is in pajamas, a sensitive little boy, his face unable to censor his shifting feelings. DAN is in shirt and tie, his jacket neatly hung on the back of a chair.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: There you are, son. You're never going to be a big boy if you don't eat your breakfast. You're going to be’the big brother. It's a very important job.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Is Mommy getting up this morning?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Of course she is. Of course Mommy's getting up. She just needs her rest. Look. Here she is. And indeed, LAURA has now appeared in the doorway, the bulge of an early to mid-term pregnancy visible. LAURA shakes her head at the sight of the white roses on the table. There's something odd, distant in her manner.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Happy birthday.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Morning, honey.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh, Dan. Roses. On your own birthday. You're too much, really. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll eat it now that you're here. DAN gestures at RICHIE.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It's your birthday. You shouldn't be out buying me flowers.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Well, you were still sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Well, we decided it would be better if we let you sleep ina little. Didn't we? DAN smiles conspiratorially at his son. LAURA reaches down and kisses RICHIE.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Good morning, bug. Co DAN You need to rest, Laura. You're only four months away.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Honestly! I'm fine. I'm just tired. DAN touches her stomach tenderly. LAURA smiles, but then slips away. She pours herself coffee. DAN is putting his jacket on over his dazzling white shirt, readying himself for work.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I've been telling him he's got to eat his breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That's true.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: So it's a beautiful day. What are you two going to be doing with it?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: co Oh, we've got our plans, haven't : we? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: What plans?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it wouldn't be much of a party, would it, if I told you every detail in advance?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Then I'd better stop asking questions then, huh? DAN grins at RICHIE, the whole performance for his benefit.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Hey, is that the time? I'd better get going. DAN is looking at his watch. It's a morning ritual -- the same every day. He gathers his briefcase and heads for the door in haste.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Have a good day.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You too.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: And, Dan... DAN stops at the door.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Happy birthday.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Thank you. DAN'S gone. Without him, the room feels silent. RICHIE looks at his mother. It's as if she's nervous at being left alone with RICHIE. LAURA waves good-bye to DAN outside in the drive, then turns back to RICHIE.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You need to finish your breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: That's what I'm doing. LAURA comes and sits at the table. RICHIE watches her, expectant. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: co

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: So. I'm going to make a cake. That's what I'm going to do. I'm going to make the cake for Daddy's birthday.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Mommie, can I help?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Can I help make the cake? LAURA frowns a second, as if regretting her son's eagerness.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Of course you can, sweet pea. I'm not going to do anything without you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SALLY appears from the bedroom and looks down to the living room where she sees CLARISSA can be heard on the phone. SALLY is pulling on her jeans. The whole apartment is submerged in books -- bound proofs, hardbacks and manuscripts.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: No, of course you must come. I mean it. I always wanted you to come. And everyone involved in the actual ceremony. CLARISSA acknowledges SALLY with a wave of the hand. SALLY turns and goes into the kitchen while CLARISSA goes back to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I don't know. Around sixty. Well it will, it will mean so much. The whole occasion. And so the least I can do is have you all to dinner. Just to say thank you. I mean it. Of course. SALLY is gone into the kitchen to pour hot coffee. She looks into the sink at the wriggling crabs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: My God, what if nobody comes? I suppose we can live for a month off crustaceans. SALLY comes back into the room with her coffee and watches CLARISSA, who is still working her charm on the phone. SALLY mimics her, wordlessly.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Oh, I take that as a yes. Oh, that's great. I'm thrilled. 0h, good. SALLY smiles affectionately at how characteristic of CLARISSA this whole conversation has been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is shining as CLARISSA appears at the top of the little run of steps from her apartment and heads cheerfully out onto 10th Street. It's a dazzling day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARISSA heads down Fifth Avenue in good spirits. Rappers go by, skate-boarders. A few PASSERS-BY greet her as she moves through the district, a familiar figure, at ease in her favorite quarter. She is on a mobile phone, still making her arrangements for the party.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: This is Clarissa Vaughan. Yes, I'm just confirming that you're sending the car to pick me up first. Yeah, and then we're going...

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Hi, Clarissa!

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Hi, hi, can't talk. CLARISSA waves and returns to her mobile.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: And then we're going over to six seventy-five Hudson. That's right. Between Fourteenth and Ninth. Then uptown. And there I will need you to wait. And it'll be over at seven.  21 22 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now CLARISSA is pausing for traffic and walking across Spring Street towards an exquisite flower shop, which is decked in buckets of summer blooms. CLARISSA heads cheerfully towards the glass door and goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARISSA goes into the chic little flower shop and raises her arms a little to greet the owner. Her name is BARBARA -- in her fifties, pale, with dark hair.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Flowers! What a beautiful morning! BARBARA kisses CLARISSA and puts an arm round her, the two of them at ease.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Clarissa, hi! How are you?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I'm having a party! My friend Richard's won the Carrouthers.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Well, that's just terrific. If I knew what it was.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: It's a poetry prize. For a life's work. It's the most prestigious. For a poet it's the best you can do.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Oh. Very good. CLARISSA is proud on Richard's behalf but BARBARA is already pointing along the rows of flowers.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: So what would you like? We've got loads of lilies...

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: No. Too morbid. Hydrangeas, I think. And let's just have buckets of roses. Whatever. To hell with it. Spare no expense. CLARISSA picks out one bunch of flowers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I'm going to take these with me. BARBARA gets out armfuls of yellow roses and takes them to the desk, while an ASSISTANT takes the ones CLARISSA has picked out to take back herself. CLARISSA wanders up the other end. Now BARBARA is cutting the stalks and wrapping them.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: I actually tried to read Richard's novel.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Oh, did you? I know it's not easy. BARBARA smiles, not unkindly, at the understatement.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I know. It did take him ten years to write.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I figured. Maybe it just takes another ten to read. CLARISSA just smiles, coming to the counter to collect her flowers.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: It's you, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: In the novel? Isn't it meant to be you?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Oh, I see. Yeah. CLARISSA shrugs, half-pleased, half-embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I mean, in a way. Sort of. Richard's a writer. That's what he is. He uses things which actually happen.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: And years ago, he and I were students, it's true. But then he changes things.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I don't mean in a bad way. BARBARA looks at her a moment. CLARISSA frowns.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: More like, he makes them his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIRGINIA WOOLF sits in her study, pen poised. She speaks to herself.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: A woman's whole life...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARISSA comes out of the flower shop, carrying a bunch of flowers and sets off down the street. VIRGINIA continues speaking underneath.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... in a single day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAURA sits thinking at the kitchen table, turning the pages of a cookery book.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Just one day... and in that day, her whole life. RICHIE has run across the kitchen and now climbs his mother's lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now CLARISSA is walking through the meat market, carrying her distinctive bunch of flowers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She crosses the road among the meat trucks. And then she approaches the huge, red-painted triangular building which looms up at her from the crossroads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At an upstairs window a MAN in a dressing gown parts his curtain to look down at CLARISSA approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARISSA, confident, cheerful, approaches a doorway crammed between the metal criss-crossings of fire escapes. She opens the door with a key and goes into a tiny, squalid, airless lobby. A fluorescent panel splutters on the ceiling. CLARISSA heads for the cheerless graffiti-strewn freight elevator, closes the gate and rides upward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARISSA rings the bell of RICHARD'S apartment, then presses her face close to the door to listen.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (inside) Mrs. Dalloway, it's you.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Yes, it's me.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (inside) Come in. CLARISSA turns the lock with her own key and goes in to a desolate loft space. The first space is in near darkness, a gloomy kitchen-bathroom area. CLARISSA picks her way carefully through to the second, larger space -- the living area -- where the man at the window is sitting, pale, stick-limbed, in a rotting armchair which is covered in towels. RICHARD is in his late 40s, gaunt from AIDS, a noble skull merely, his boxer's nose and high forehead lit by a streak of light from between the blinds. He is wearing a blue robe with child-like drawings of rockets and astronauts on it. The whole place is bleached, chaotic, more or less bare of ornament. This is a man who has pared his life down to very little. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CLARISSA puts down the flowers and goes to the blinds.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Richard, it's a beautiful morning. How about I let in a little light?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Is it still morning?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: It is. CLARISSA raises one of the shades. RICHARD barely moves to greet the light.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Have I died? Am I alive? CLARISSA bends over and kisses his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Good morning, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Any visitors?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Are they still here?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No. They've gone.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: How did they look?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Today? Sort of like black fire. I mean, sort of light and dark at the same time. There was one a bit like an electrified jellyfish. CLARISSA looks at him a moment, then picks up the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: They were singing. It may have been Greek.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: You don't sleep at all, do you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: o RICHARD . Oh, sleep. CLARISSA has gone into the kitchen and calls back through to him.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I saw three bluebirds on the way over. Do you think it's a good omen?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Do you believe in omens? Omens would mean someone was looking after us, someone was watching. Do you believe anyone's watching? Do they send signs? RICHARD makes a sort of grin, amused at the idea.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I mean, I'd love to believe it.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: The ceremony's at five. Do you Co remember?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Do I? Do I remember?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Then the party's after. CLARISSA has arranged the flowers and now she reappears in the doorway of Richard's room. CLARISSA looks at him tolerantly, the long-suffering look of nurse to patient. His complex cocktail of pills is laid out neatly ona table nearby.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: They did bring you breakfast, didn't they?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What a question. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: You did eat it, Richard?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Well can you see it? Is there any o breakfast lying around? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cc 29

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I can't see it.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Well, then, I must have eaten it, mustn't I?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Does it matter?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Of course it matters. You know what the doctors say. Have you been skipping pills? CLARISSA is frowning mistrustfully at the way the cocktail is laid out on the table but RICHARD is suddenly impatient, ignoring the question.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Clarissa, I can't take this.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Take what?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Having to be proud and brave in front of everybody.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Honey, it's not a performance.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Of course it is. I got the prize for my performance.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Well, that is nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I got the prize for having AIDS and going nuts and being brave about it. I actually got the prize for having come through.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: It's not true. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: For surviving. That's what I got the prize for. You think they'd give it to me if I were healthy?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Well, yes, as a matter of fact I do. RICHARD looks at her with an ironic gleam of doubt.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Is it here somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: The prize. I'd like to look at it.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: You haven't gotten it yet. It's tonight.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Are you sure? I remember the ceremony perfectly. I seem to have fallen out of time. CLARISSA waits a moment, trying to be patient.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Richard, it's a party. It's only a party. Populated entirely by people who respect and admire you.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Ah, small party, is it? Select party, is it?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Your friends.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I thought I lost all my friends. I drove my friends crazy. RICHARD reaches out and touches the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: ‘Oh Mrs. Dalloway, always giving parties to cover the silence...' (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CLARISSA is stunned a moment by his unkindness, and then rallies, keeping her anger at bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard, you won't need to do anything. All you have to do is appear, sit on the sofa. And I will be there. This is a group of people who want to tell you your work's going to live.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Is it? Is my work going to live? RICHARD looks at her without pity.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I can't go through with it, Clarissa.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Because I wanted to be a writer, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: So? RICHARD gets up, heaving himself across the room on a crutch.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I wanted to write about it all. Everything that's happening in a moment. The way those flowers looked when you carried them in your arms -- this towel, how it smells, how it feels -- this thread -- all our feelings, yours and mine. The history of who we once were. Everything that's in the world. Everything mixed up. Like it's all mixed up now. RICHARD'S eyes fill with tears. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: And I failed. Whatever you start with, it ends up so much less. Sheer fucking pride and stupidity. RICHARD slumps down again. CLARISSA watches, part impatient, part helpless.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: We want everything, don't we?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Yes. I suppose we do.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You kissed me on a beach...

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You remember?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: How many years ago? CLARISSA shakes her head, too overwhelmed to answer.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What did you want then? Again, CLARISSA says nothing. She is as upset as he is.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Come here, come closer, would you please?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I'm right here.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Take my hand. CLARISSA takes his painfully-thin hand, a handful of twigs.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Would you be angry? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Would I be angry if you didn't show up at the party?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No. Would you be angry if I died?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: If you died? Would I be angry if you died?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Who's this party for?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Who's it for? What are you asking? What are you trying to say?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I'm not trying to say anything! I'm saying! CLARISSA is panicking now.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I think I'm only staying alive to satisfy you. CLARISSA is looking at him, aghast.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: So? Well? That's what we do. That's what people do. They stay alive for each other. The doctors told you: you don't need to die. The doctors told you that. You can live like this for years.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Well exactly. RICHARD smiles, CLARISSA bitterly shakes her head, firm now.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I don't accept this. I don't accept what you're saying.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Oh, what? And it's you to decide is it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: . RICHARD
dialogues.text: How long have you been doing this?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Doing what?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: How many years, coming to the apartment? What about your own life? What about Sally? Just wait till I die. Then you'll have to think of yourself. CLARISSA doesn't answer. RICHARD smiles, sure of his point.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: How are you going to like that? CLARISSA lets go of his hand, disturbed. RICHARD just looks at her. CLARISSA gets up and stands a moment, shaken. Then speaks quietly.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Richard, it would be great if you did come. If you felt well enough to come. Just to let you know: I'm making the crab thing. Not that I imagine it makes any difference.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Of course it makes a difference. I love the crab thing. CLARISSA is about to leave but RICHARD calls across to her.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Clarissa?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Yes? RICHARD raises his head slightly for her to kiss him. CLARISSA puts her lips next to his, with great tenderness, not to hurt him. Then she squeezes his shoulder. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I'll come back at three-thirty to help you get dressed.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Wonderful. CLARISSA goes out. The sound of the apartment DOOR being RE-OPENED and then CLOSED. RICHARD is alone.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARISSA, in her dark glasses, gets back into the freight elevator, distraught from her encounter. She throws her head back in despair at the side of the elevator. The elevator goes down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIRGINIA WOOLF is still at her desk, just as before. But now the first pages of her notebook are filled with handwriting. She speaks again to herself.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: It's on this day, this day of all days, her fate becomes clear to her... At once there is a loud KNOCK at the door, interrupting VIRGINIA'S thoughts. Without waiting for an answer, NELLY BOXALL appears. She is large, red-faced, regal, in cook's apron.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mrs. Woolf, Mr. Woolf said I was to come and speak to you.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: I can't imagine why he said that. NELLY, unyielding, ignores VIRGINIA'S tone.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: I'm nearly finished, Nelly. Please attend me in the kitchen and I'll be down very soon.  32 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIRGINIA is coming downstairs. She stops, standing with her back against the wall in the corridor outside the kitchen, preparing herself for the encounter ahead. From inside she can hear NELLY chattering freely with LOTTIE.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: What happens is, she says she wants something then it turns out she doesn’t...

dialogues.speaker: LOTTIE
dialogues.text: Well she never does, does she? Never wants anything.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Especially when she's asked for it. That's a sure sign.

dialogues.speaker: LOTTIE
dialogues.text: I wish I'd been there.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I wish you had, too. The two women laugh cheerfully. VIRGINIA summons up her courage.

dialogues.speaker: LOTTIE
dialogues.text: Did you give her that look? That sort of look you do?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I said, 'Madam'... But before Nelly can finish, VIRGINIA has stepped into the open door and cut her off. NELLY is rolling out pastry and cutting huge chunks of raw lamb. Beside her, LOTTIE is working. She is in her teens, dressed identically to NELLY, and collusive, not missing a trick.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Yes, Nelly, tell me, how can I help? VIRGINIA moves towards the table, trying to take charge of her formidable servant.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: It's about lunch.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Ah, yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I just had to go ahead on my own.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: I understand. VIRGINIA recoils slightly at the sight and smell of raw meat.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: You chose a pie?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I chose a lamb pie.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: That seems suitable.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: You being so busy with your writing. VIRGINIA does not respond. LOTTIE works on, impassive.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I had no instructions. And I thought some of them yellow pears for pudding, unless you'd like something fancier.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Pears will be fine. NELLY lifts up pastry and folds it into the pan, a figure of righteous hard work.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: You do remember that my sister is coming at four with the family?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am, I haven't forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: China tea, I think. And ginger. NELLY hesitates in her actions. LOTTIE registers the moment also.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: Ginger, madam? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: I'd like to give the children a treat.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: We'd have to go to London for ginger, ma'am I haven't finished this and there's the rest of the lunch to get ready. VIRGINIA steels herself, not rising to the bait.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: The twelve-thirty train, Nelly, will get you to London just after one. If you return on the two- thirty, you will be back in Richmond soon after three. Do I miscalculate?

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Well then. It's a trial of strength. NELLY doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Well then? Is something detaining you, Nelly? VIRGINIA is tense. But she knows she's won. NELLY puts down the rolling pin.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: I can't think of anything more exhilarating than a trip to London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIRGINIA descends the stairs to the print room. The room is overflowing with manuscripts. In the middle of the untidiness, LEONARD sits with a scowl, scrutinizing proofs. Beside him, a handsome young man, RALPH PARTRIDGE, is working at the inky hand-operated printing press.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Good morning. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mrs. Woolf. RALPH looks up, relieved to see her. The atmosphere is extremely tense.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: We shall publish no more new authors. I have to tell you I have discovered ten errors in the first proof.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Lucky to have found them, then, Leonard.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: ‘Paschendale was a charnel-house from which no min returned.' Do you think it is possible that bad writing actually attracts a higher incidence of error? VIRGINIA is smiling.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: If it's all right, I thought I might take a short walk.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Not far?

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: No. Just for air. LEONARD now gives imperceptible consent -- just with his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Go then. If I could walk mid- morning, I'd be a very happy man. VIRGINIA pauses a moment at the barb, then goes. RALPH watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a school next to Hogarth House and children in the playground. VIRGINIA comes along the pavement in front of the railings, lost in a world of her own. She walks a little, then stops, without realizing, and talks to herself. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: She'll die. She's going to die. That's what's going to happen. A couple of people pass, noticing that this vague, genteel woman is talking to herself. Now VIRGINIA stares at a couple of little SCHOOLGIRLS in the playground, one earnestly whispering to the other, both intent.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: That's it. She will kill herself. She will kill herself over something which doesn't seem to matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAURA is still in her dressing gown, but now with an apron tied over it. She is sitting frowning at a recipe book on the surface in front of her. Beside her she has assembled all the elements of cake-making -- eggs, tins, sugar and a series of pale blue bowls. But the endeavor is stalled. RICHIE is standing beside her, waiting patiently.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Let's think.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: You grease the pan, Mommy.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I know you grease the pan, sweet one. Even Mommy knows that. Decisively she reaches to assemble the elements. RICHIE frowns, watching.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Okay. This is what we're going to do. Flour. Bowl. Sifter.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Can I do it, Mommy?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Can you sift the flour? LAURA smiles at him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes, you can sift the flour, baby, if that's what makes you happy.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: I'd like to.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Okay. You do that. LAURA gives RICHIE a sieve, then pours the raw flour in for him to shake out. RICHIE concentrates with great seriousness. Flour falls through the sieve in a fine white powder into a blue china bowl. LAURA has

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Isn't it beautiful? Don’t you think it looks like snow? gone back to looking at the recipe book again.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Next -- now this is the next thing. I'm going to show you. The next thing is we measure out the cups.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Mommy, it isn't that difficult.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I know, sweet pea. I know it isn't difficult. It's just... I want to do this for Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Because it's his birthday.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That's right. We're baking the cake to show him we love him.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Otherwise he won't know we love him? LAURA looks at her son a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That's right.  36 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARISSA is sitting immobilized in the second bedroom. The room is stacked with spare furniture which has been cleared away to make room for the party. CLARISSA has sat down on a hard chair, still trying to recover from her earlier encounter with RICHARD. Through the front door, full of cheerfulness, comes SALLY, carrying armfuls of dry cleaning and a load of Balducci bags.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I got all the stuff. My God, what a zoo. Why do people have to talk about dry cleaning? I mean what is there to talk about? SALLY has gone straight through to their own bedroom to put the dry cleaning down on the bed. Now SALLY has come out into the corridor and is heading with the shopping bags towards the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I bought you some flowers. SALLY sees she has been pre-empted by the abundant flowers CLARISSA has already brought home. She throws her own offering down beside them.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: In here. SALLY has put the bags down in the kitchen, and is beginning to get oranges out of them.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I got somebody to cover for me at work. I'll be with you all night. SALLY opens the fridge door and starts putting oranges inside. She frowns slightly at the silence from CLARISSA.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Sure. Sally smiles to herself, not worried by CLARISSA'S slump.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I guess you saw Richard. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Well, of course. I bet he said, ‘Oh by the way, honey, d'you mind, can I skip the party? CLARISSA nods resignedly at SALLY'S prescience. In the other room, SALLY, still unloading oranges, nods in psychic response. SALLY, in

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Don't worry. Finally. He always shows up.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Oh sure.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: In the end. What, Richard miss an award? A chance to talk about his work? I don't think so. He'll show up. perpetual motion, has now come upon the table- party plan, a mixture of names and circles, which is laid out on the table. SALLY has

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: You did the seating?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I don't believe it. Louis Waters. Richard's Louis? Is he coming?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: He is.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: You put me next to him. Why do I always get to sit next to the ex's? Is this a hint, sweetheart? Anyway, shouldn't ex's have a table of their own? Where they can all ex together. In exquisite agony. appeared at the jamb of the second bedroom. CLARISSA looks up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I'm off. Try not to pass out from excitement. Clarissa, it's going to be beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: No problem. SALLY turns and goes out. CLARISSA is alone. The apartment is silent.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Why is everything wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAURA is looking at the finished cake. It isn't what she'd hoped. She has tried to pipe out the message "HAPPY BIRTHDAY DAN" on top. But the lettering is clumsy, and there are crumbs in the icing. LAURA speaks under her breath.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It didn't work. Damn! It didn't work. At once there is the sound of the back DOORBELL. LAURA looks, seeing the outline of a woman at the door. She begins to panic, checking in the mirror, alarmed to see herself, still in her bathrobe, looking like a distressed person. RICHIE has come running in, holding a red plastic toy he has been playing with.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Mommy! Mommy! There's someone at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a few seconds later. LAURA swings open the door, having made a hurried attempt at normality. Her hair is tidier, but she is still in the robe. At the back door. KITTY is standing, a little younger than LAURA, and more confident, with a voluptuous, good-looking presence: well made-up, well turned out, at ease. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Hi, Kitty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Am I interrupting?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Of course not. Come in.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Are you all right? KITTY comes through the door. It's true: LAURA looks a little wild-eyed, desperate.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Why, sure.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Hi, Richie!

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Sit down. I've got coffee on. Would you like some?

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Please. RICHIE is on the floor, observing from a distance. KITTY sits at the kitchen table and sees the sugary heap.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Oh look -- you made a cake.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I know. It didn't work. I thought it was going to work. I thought it would work better than that.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Honestly, Laura, I don't know why you find it so difficult.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I don't know either.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Anyone can make a cake.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I know. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Everyone can. It's ridiculously easy. Like I bet you didn't grease the pan.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I greased the pan. KITTY smiles. LAURA is getting cups, pouring coffee.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: All right, but you have other virtues. And Dan loves you so much he won't even notice. Whatever you do, he's going to say it's wonderful. LAURA looks at her reproachfully and pushes KITTY'S coffee across to her.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Well it's true.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Does Ray have a birthday?

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Sure he does.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: When is it?

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: September. We go to the country club. We always go to the country club. We drink Martinis and spend the day with fifty people.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Ray's got a lot of friends.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: He does.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You've both have a lot of friends. You're good at it. LAURA has said this without envy, and KITTY smiles, accepting the compliment. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: How is Ray? I haven't seen him in a while.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Ray's fine. Hmm. They both smile.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: These guys are something, aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You can say that again. They came home from the war, they deserved it, didn't they? After what they'd been through?

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: What did they deserve?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I don't know. Us, I guess. All this. LAURA gestures ‘round the prosperous surroundings. KITTY nods at the copy of Mrs. Dalloway on the kitchen

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Oh. You're reading a book?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: What's this one about?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh, it's about this woman who's incredibly... well, she's a hostess and she's incredibly confident. And she's going to give a party. And... maybe, because she's confident, everyone thinks she's fine. But she isn’t. KITTY has picked up the book and now takes a glance at The talk's run out.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: So. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Well.

dialogues.speaker: . LAURA
dialogues.text: What is it? Is something wrong, Kitty? KITTY gathers herself for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: I have to go into the hospital for a ‘couple of days.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Kitty...

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: I have some kind of growth in... in my uterus. They're going to go in and take a look.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: This afternoon. LAURA just looks at her, not knowing how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: I need you to feed the dog.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Of course. There's a moment's silence. KITTY puts her front door key on the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Is that what you came to ask? KITTY just looks at her, not answering.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What did the doctor say, exactly?

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: It's probably what the trouble's been. About getting pregnant. KITTY looks at LAURA a moment, unused to confidences. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: The thing is, I mean, you know, I've been really happy with Ray, but well... now it turns out there was a reason... there was a reason I couldn't conceive. You're lucky, Laura. I don't think you can call yourself a woman until you're a mother. LAURA looks down at her own stomach. KITTY looks away.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: The joke is: all my life I could do everything -- I mean, I can do anything -- really -- I never had any trouble -- except the one thing I wanted.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: That's all.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Well, at least now they'll be able to deal with it.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: That's right. That's what they're doing.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That's right. KITTY is rubbing her thumb against her forefinger, as at an imaginary stain.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: I'm not worried. What would be the point of worrying?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No. It's not in your hands.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: That's it. It's in the hands of some physician I've never met...

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Kitty... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: ... some surgeon who probably drinks even more martinis than Ray, and no doubt always takes a six-iron to the green. Whatever that may mean. KITTY is losing it now, fighting to control her feelings.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: I mean, of course I'm worried for Ray.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Come here. But in fact it is LAURA who gets up and goes over to KITTY. She bends down and embraces her. After a moment, KITTY slips her arms ‘round LAURA'S waist. The two women hold onto each other, LAURA almost kneeling to be at KITTY'S level. Then, without planning it, LAURA kisses KITTY'S forehead, lingeringly. KITTY lets her.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: I'm doing fine. Really.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I know you are.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: If anything. I'm more worried about Ray. He's not good at this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Forget about Ray for a minute. Just forget about Ray. KITTY'S face is against LAURA'S breasts. She seems to relax into her. LAURA lifts KITTY'S face, and puts her lips against hers. They both know what they are doing. They kiss, letting themselves go a moment. Then LAURA pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: You're sweet. There is a brief moment, then LAURA turns and her eye falls on RICHIE who is on the floor with his toys. They had both forgotten him. He has watched throughout. KITTY stands up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: You know the routine, right? Half a can in the evening, and check the water now and then. Ray will feed him in the morning. KITTY has got up to go.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Kitty, you didn't mind?

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: What? I didn't mind what? LAURA stands, anxious.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Do you want me to drive you?

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: I think I'll feel better if I drive myself.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Kitty, it's going to be all right.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Of course it is. 'Bye. KITTY goes out. LAURA stands in the middle of the kitchen. She looks down at RICHIE who is still looking Silently up at her.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What? What do you want? It is said just sharply enough to make RICHIE turn and go silently to his own room. LAURA looks at him going, then walks across to the kitchen top. Then, needing to do something decisive, LAURA picks up the cake which is cooling on a rack. LAURA opens a pedal bin with her foot, and slides the cake off the plate cleanly into the bin. It makes a satisfyingly-solid noise as it lands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the printing room, RALPH and LEONARD are reading proofs silently. LOTTIE appears at the door.

dialogues.speaker: LOTTIE
dialogues.text: Mr. Woolf, Mrs. Bell has arrived. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bell? LEONARD looks up in exasperation, as if this were typical.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Not due till four.

dialogues.speaker: LOTTIE
dialogues.text: I can't help that. She's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Virginia's sister, VANESSA BELL, is waiting in the drawing room. Although, at 44, VANESSA is older than Virginia, she looks younger and more open, more glossy and easygoing. She is just sending her little daughter out to play in the garden as VIRGINIA arrives, followed by LOTTIE.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Virginia! They kiss. VIRGINIA laughs conspiratorially.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Leonard thinks it's the end of civilization. People who are invited at four who arrive at two- thirty...

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Oh, God.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Barbarians!

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: We finished lunch earlier than we imagined.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: I've had to pack Nelly off to London for sugared ginger. VIRGINIA is heading cheerfully out toward the garden, but VANESSA comments well within LOTTIE'S hearing.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Oh, Virginia, you're not still frightened of the servants! LOTTIE is left smiling, as the two women head into the garden.  43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: o VIRGINIA and VANESSA are sitting in the garden at Hogar * House, watching the children playing.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: And how are you, sister?

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Frantic. It's been ridiculous in London.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Ridiculous how?

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Busy.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Why is busy ridiculous?

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: I would have invited you to our party, but I knew you wouldn't come.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: o Did you? VIRGINIA looks genuinely surprised.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: How did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: I thought you never came to town.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: You no longer ask me.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Aren't you forbidden to come? Do the doctors not forbid it?

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: The doctors!

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Do you not pay heed to your doctors?

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Not when they are a bunch of o contemptible Victorians. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: VANESSA looks sideways at VIRGINIA, surprised by her forthrightness.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: So? What are you saying? Are you feeling better? Has this fastness made you stronger?

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: I'm saying, Vanessa, that even crazy people like to be asked. VIRGINIA moves on. VANESSA stops a second, briefly shocked. They are heading toward VANESSA'S three children who are gathered in a group near the bushes ‘round something not yet seen. JULIAN BELL is 15, sturdy and muscular; QUENTIN BELL is 13, looking like a young soldier; and ANGELICA GARNETT is an exceptionally- beautiful little girl of five.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Hello, changelings, what have you got? What have you found?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: We've found a bird.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Did you? Where did you find that?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I think it must have fallen from the tree. QUENTIN holds a dying thrush out in his hands, a bundle of gray feathers.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Goodness, just look at him.

dialogues.speaker: QUENTIN
dialogues.text: He's alive. I think we might be able to save him.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Save him? VANESSA frowns.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: I think you have to be careful, Quentin. There's a time to die. It may be the bird's time. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fearing such talk may upset her, VANESSA instinctively squeezes VIRGINIA'S hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Let's pick some grass. Let's pick some grass to make a grave. VANESSA is about to protest, but JULIAN interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I'm just saying then at least there'll be a bed for him to die on.

dialogues.speaker: QUENTIN
dialogues.text: Come on, Nessa, let's make a grave.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Oh God, oh very well. I'm coming. Wait for me, then. Angelica, you'll be all right? VANESSA runs off with the boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGELICA is making the little bed of twigs. The others have gone off to pick grass. VIRGINIA appears above ANGELICA with some yellow roses.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Do you think she'd like roses?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Let's put roses 'round the grass. VIRGINIA kneels down next to ANGELICA and helps her arrange the little bed. The bird is lying to one side. In the distance the boys are calling:

dialogues.speaker: BOYS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mother. There's some good stuff over here. Mother! Mother!

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: Is it a she? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Yes. The females are larger and less colorful. The sticks, grass and leaves are now laid out in a rough circle. ANGELICA'S hands have the dead bird protected inside them as she lays down the thrush, arranging her feet under her. ANGELICA and VIRGINIA decorate the circle of leaves with roses.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: What happens when we die?

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: What happens? We return to the place we came from.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: I don't remember where I came from.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Nor do I. ANGELICA frowns, trying to understand.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: She looks very small.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Yes. That's one of the things that happens. We look smaller.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: But very peaceful. VIRGINIA smiles at ANGELICA. Suddenly VANESSA arrives with the boys, her energy breaking up the moment of quiet.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Is it done? Have we finished? Is the bird funeral complete? Have bird obsequies been done?

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: They have.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Good. Very well then. Are we to be denied tea altogether for coming so early? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ANGELICA runs off, happy at the job done. But VIRGINIA doesn't yet move.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: No. Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Well, then. Come on, boys. VANESSA walks off up the lawn with JULIAN and QUENTIN. They are all chattering as they go.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Where's Nelly gone?

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: She had to go to London to get ginger.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Did that make her angry?

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Virginia says very.

dialogues.speaker: QUENTIN
dialogues.text: I like it when Nelly gets angry. It's funny. Then it's silent. VIRGINIA is left alone. She has not moved. She is still looking at the bird's grave. The bird is perfectly at peace and surrounded with petals. VIRGINIA looks. Slowly, VIRGINIA closes her eyes. Her face becomes a death mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAURA is lain out on the bed, an identical look on her face to VIRGINIA'S. Then, impulsively, she gets up from the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICHIE is sitting by himself playing on the carpet with his toys. He looks up, missing nothing, as LAURA comes out of the bedroom. She smiles absently at him, and walks across the living room to pick up the tapestry bag which is lying on a chair. She takes it with her and goes into the bathroom.  45 46 47 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAURA opens the mirrored cupboard above the sink. In it, there are a few odd bottles of aspirin, etc. She reaches for some bottles of prescribed sleeping pills. She opens the tapestry bag, puts the bottles inside and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAURA comes out of the bedroom with the tapestry bag. RICHIE looks up again, trying to puzzle out where she has been. LAURA heads straight for the kitchen, where she puts the bag on a high surface, out of the child's reach. LAURA reaches once more for the flour and eggs.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Hey, bug, I've got this idea. We're going to make another cake. We're going to make a better one.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: What happened to the first one? LAURA smiles at him as if everything were completely normal.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Then after that, I think we should go out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At once a man's finger pressing the intercom. LOUIS WATERS is leonine, silvery, handsome, in his late 40s, casually but perfectly dressed: a once-startlingly good- looking man, now a little faded. He is nervous. It's taken him an effort to RING the BELL. After a moment he hears CLARISSA'S voice.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Clarissa, it's Louis. Louis Waters.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Louis? My God. You're early.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Do you mind? Is it all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARISSA has pressed the BUZZER and LOUIS is coming into the vestibule of the building. As he does, CLARISSA swings open the door of the apartment to greet him. She has an apron around her waist and green plastic gloves on. Her hair is a mess and LOUIS has plainly interrupted her in mid-work. She is listening to a CD, which is BOOMING out behind her.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Why should I mind? I'm delighted.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Well now. They fall into each other's arms, embracing. They hold each other some time, with real need. Then CLARISSA lets go and sees that Louis' eyes are moist.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I feel I'm interrupting.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Why, no.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I know the ceremony's not till five, but I flew in this morning. CLARISSA stands a moment, shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Richard's going to be thrilled. He'll be thrilled to see you.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Of course. Of course he will. There's just a moment's hesitation.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: What are we doing? We should go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARISSA leads LOUIS into the apartment, taking off her apron. LOUIS follows her, hesitant, wondering what is wrong beyond her astonishment at seeing him again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. It's nothing. just the party.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Oh, right. LOUIS looks around the room. to the sides. Yellow roses abound. 50. 49 It's Everything is now cleared There are bunches of flowers everywhere. CLARISSA TURNS OFF the CD of JESSYE NORMAN SINGING one of Strauss' last songs.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Wow. you still with...

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm still with her. years. It's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Why is it crazy? It's looking beautiful. Are Ten CLARISSA shakes her head, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: No reason. Would you like a drink?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Some water.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARISSA lifts the lid on the big pot is now bubbling on the stove. Around ingredients to make crab souffle roll CLARISSA takes a look, then takes off fills glasses with ice and carbonated through the kitchen to where LOUIS is still admiring the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: And you're still an editor? 50 of shellfish, which the kitchen, the are laid out. her plastic gloves, water. She looks standing alone, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Oh, sure.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Still with the same publisher? CLARISSA nods.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: How's San Francisco?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Oh. It's one of those cities people tell you to like. LOUIS stops a moment looking at a framed photograph of the young RICHARD, looking handsome, healthy and young.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Richard said he thought you were happy out there.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Oh great. So now the illness makes him psychic? CLARISSA hands him his water.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Louis, you have to prepare yourself. He's very changed. LOUIS has picked out a copy of RICHARD'S book from CLARISSA'S shelves. CLARISSA goes back to her cooking.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I read the book...

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Oh, God!

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Exactly. I thought you were meant to do more than just change people's names.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Isn't it meant to be fiction? He even had you living on Tenth Street. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: o~ CLARISSA frowns, not liking the way the conversation i ° going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't me.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: You know how Richard is. It's a fantasy.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: A whole chapter about 'Should she buy some nail polish?' And then guess what? After fifty pages she doesn't! CLARISSA smiles, but LOUIS isn't amused.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: The whole thing seems to go on for eternity. Nothing happens. Then wham! For no reason she kills o herself.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: His mother kills herself.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sure. His mother. But still for no reason.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Out of the blue. LOUIS seems annoyed, but CLARISSA speaks quietly, trying to reach him now.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I know the book is tough. But I liked it. I know. Only one thing upset me.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? What was that? What upset you?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LOUIS is looking at her warily now, as if he fears being hurt.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Well... that there wasn't more about you.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: That's kind. LOUIS looks up, caught off balance. Now he is moved, and risks a confidence.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I went back to Wellfleet.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: One day. I didn't tell you.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: No. But then I never see you.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: You remember the house? It's still there. Louis stops, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I think you're courageous.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Courageous? Why?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: To dare to go visit. LOUIS frowns.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: What I mean is: to face the fact we've lost those feelings forever. CLARISSA'S eyes are full of tears, and she seems to have forgotten LOUIS is there.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Clarissa... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I don't know what's happening. I'm sorry. I seem to be in some strange sort of mood. I seem to be unraveling...

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Clarissa, I shouldn't have come. CLARISSA holds out a hand to stop him coming over to comfort her.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: No, it's not you. Really. It's more... it's like having a presentiment. Do you know what I'm saying? CLARISSA wipes her eyes, tries to make light of it.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Oh, God, it's probably just nerves about the party. Bad hostess. Suddenly CLARISSA sinks to the floor, not able to control herself anymore.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Clarissa, what's happening?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: What is it? CLARISSA has gone away to the wall, like a child now, with her hand raised to hide her face.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Oh, God!

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Do you want me to go? CLARISSA tires desperately to turn her grief to anger.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: No. Don't go. Explain to me! Why is this happening? LOUIS moves towards her to try and reassure her by taking her in his arms. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: co CLARISSA No. Don't touch me. It's better you don't. LOUIS stands useless. CLARISSA looks at him a moment through her tears. Then she tries desperately.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: It's too much. It's just too much. You fly in from San Francisco. I've been nursing Richard for years...

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: And all that time I've held myself together... no problem... There's a silence. Neither of them can say anything. CLARISSA just looks pleadingly at him from the floor.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Yes. ‘ Neither speaks. CLARISSA wipes her tears with her sleeve. She's quiet when she talks.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: One morning. In Wellfleet. You were there. We were all there. I'd been sleeping with him and I was on the back porch. He came out. He put his hand on my shoulder. 'Good morning, Mrs. Dalloway.' CLARISSA is lost a moment in the memory.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: And ever since then, I've been stuck.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Stuck?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I mean, with the name. There's a silence. Then CLARISSA gestures towards LOUIS, co to divert. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: o CLARISSA And now you walk in... to see you walk in. Because I never see you. Look at you! LOUIS looks at her, wanting to help.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Anyway, it doesn't matter. It was you he stayed with. It was you he lived with. I had one summer. You'll see when he comes. He's still Richard. His mind wanders and he's in a lot of pain. But there's some constant quality. There's his Richard-ness. LOUIS moves towards her, careful about what he wants to spell out.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: The day I left him I got ona train and made my way across Europe. I felt free for the first time in years. eo There is a silence. CLARISSA stares, taking in what LOUIS has just said. Then she gets up, trying to get back to normal.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: So. You must tell me about San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: What's to tell? I still teach drama to idiots. Mostly.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: They can't all be idiots.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: No. LOUIS has put his glass down.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: No, in fact... I shouldn't tell you this: I've fallen in love.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
