dialogues.text: o Really? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Yes. With a student.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: A student?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Exactly. LOUIS acknowledges the absurdity of it.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I know. You think 'Am I still up for this? All this intensity...' All those arguments, doors being slammed... well, you know what it's like... CLARISSA says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Are you feeling better?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: A little. Thank you. CLARISSA goes to the sink. LOUIS is suddenly embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Do you think I'm ridiculous?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Ridiculous. Fortunate, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAURA takes a second cake out of the oven and sets it down on a cake rack. She looks at it a moment. It is much better than the first. It reads HAPPY BIRTHDAY DAN and is fringed with yellow roses. LAURA takes off her oven gloves and reaches for the tapestry bag. She goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tapestry bag lands with a wham! on the back seat of the car. LAURA then bundles a rather surprised-looking RICHIE into the passenger seat. Then LAURA goes 'round and gets in the driver's side. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm going to leave you at Mrs. Latch's. I have to do something. LAURA is dressed and made-up, armored to go out into the world. RICHIE is looking at her as she STARTS the CAR.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Mommy, I don't want to go.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You have to. I'm sorry. I have to do something before Daddy comes home. They drive off down the suburban street, fringed with palm trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cute suburban house with plaster squirrels on the gable over the garage. MRS. LATCH, a big, florid woman in Bermuda shorts, opens the door. RICHIE is holding LAURA'S hand, and looking very reluctant to go into the house.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LATCH
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Hi, Mrs. Latch. My boy's not very happy.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Mommy, I don't want to do this.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I have to go, honey. LAURA stoops down to his level and kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LATCH
dialogues.text: Your mommy has things she must do. If you come in, I got cookies. LAURA takes him so that she can look him directly in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Baby. Baby, you have to be brave now. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LATCH
dialogues.text: Don't you worry, he's going to be fine. MRS. LATCH reaches out and takes RICHIE'S hand. Turned away now from her son, LAURA walks across the lawn back to the car. Without warning, her face crumples in tears, but as she reaches the car she wipes her eyes with her hand to hide her distress. Then she turns back to wave.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Honey! RICHIE waves back from the step. LAURA quickly gets into the car, grinning at him. She can barely get the key in the starter, but when she does, she turns and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAURA is beginning to drive away down the road. She looks nervously in the rearview mirror. She sees RICHIE run out of MRS. LATCH'S arms and into the road screaming desperately.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Mommy! Mommy! No! LAURA swings the wheel decisively to the left and with a little SQUEAL of RUBBER, accelerates away. RICHIE stands alone in the middle of the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now LAURA is cruising on a Los Angeles freeway. For a moment, her higher speed and the freedom of the road gives the feeling that she has successfully escaped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in the living room of Mrs. Latch's house, RICHIE moodily gets out a building set and begins building a small house. MRS. LATCH watches from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAURA drives intently. She is aimless, distressed. But then she looks to the side of the freeway where there is a sign for the Normandy Hotel. Impulsively, with no pre- planning, LAURA swings the car dangerously across lanes and takes it out along the slipway towards the hotel.  58 59 60 61 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICHIE has finished the little house. Now he picks up the complete building and tumbles it bad-temperedly back into the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAURA walks towards a huge wedding-cake hotel, a pseudo- Spanish '50s palace. She carries no luggage except her tapestry bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAURA has checked into the hotel and is now standing in the room she has reserved. It is featureless, anonymous -- green spreads and candy wallpaper. LAURA is dropping fifty cents into a HOTEL CLERK'S outstretched hand.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Breakfast is served between seven and eleven in the Regency Room. There's a swimming pool at the back, and the hotel is open for twenty-four hours. He pockets his tip.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Thank you, ma'am. Is there anything else you need? LAURA hesitates a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes. No. Not to be disturbed. He goes out. LAURA is left alone. She looks around the room. There is a moment of silence, of relief. LAURA looks ‘round, not quite knowing what to do next. LAURA sits on the edge of the bed and opens her bag. She takes out the pale green toilet bag and unzips it. She takes the little rank of pill bottles out and sets them down on the bed cover. As she does so, she sees her copy of Mrs. Dalloway at the bottom of the tapestry bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now LAURA is stretched out reading on the bed, a pillow against her back. AS LAURA reads her book, the text is heard in VIRGINIA'S voice. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Did it matter, then, she asked herself, walking towards Bond Street, did it matter that she must inevitably cease completely... LAURA pulls her blouse out from her skirt to loosen it, and puts her hand on her pregnant stomach.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: All this must go on without her; did she resent it; or did it not become consoling to believe that death ended absolutely? LAURA rubs her naked stomach slightly, feeling the child within.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It is possible to die. Suddenly brackish water floods from underneath, washing up over the sides of the bed. LAURA, in her imagination, sinks under the water, strewn with weeds, and then drowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIRGINIA is sitting with VANESSA having tea. JULIAN and QUENTIN are at the other end of the room. VIRGINIA is completely lost in her own thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It is possible to die. VIRGINIA turns her head and becomes aware that VANESSA has been speaking. She only hears the end of what has obviously been a long discourse.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: ... There was a lovely coat for Angelica at Harrods, but then nothing for the boys and it seemed so unfair. Why should Angelica be favored? VIRGINIA does not reply.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Virginia? Virginia? What are you thinking about? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: VIRGINIA is still looking at her a little blankly. JULIAN and QUENTIN are nudging each other, laughing at how odd VIRGINIA is.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Are you still with us? ANGELICA runs across to VIRGINIA, who scoops her up and puts her on her knee. .

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Your aunt's a very lucky woman, Angelica, because she has two lives. Most of us have only one. But she has the life she leads and she also has the book she's writing. This makes her very fortunate indeed. VIRGINIA smiles at ANGELICA on her knee.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: What were you thinking about?

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Oh. I was going to kill my heroine. But I've changed my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in the (dry) bedroom, LAURA is lying on the bed, the pills still visible on the table beside her. She still has the book in front of her, but she is not reading it. She puts it to one side. Then she rubs her naked stomach again. Her eyes fill with tears.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I can't! I can't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIRGINIA is just as before.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: I fear I may have to kill someone else instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is now gathered in the hall, saying good-bye. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There is a car waiting outside which is being loaded. QUENTIN, JULIAN and ANGELICA are all in front as VANESSA and VIRGINIA make their way to the door.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: It was a fascinating visit. They enjoyed it thoroughly.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Do you have to go already? I do wish you wouldn't go.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Why, Virginia, the last thing you need is our noisiness. My hopeless, clumsy boys. VANESSA smiles at the lads.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Say good-bye, boys.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Good-bye, children. The boys say "Good-bye" and "Good-bye, Aunt" and shake VIRGINIA'S hand. They go out of the front door towards a waiting taxi. VIRGINIA turns to her sister.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: And you will return to what? To concerts? To parties?

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Tonight? An insufferable dinner which not even you could envy, Virginia.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: But I do. Suddenly she looks VANESSA in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Kiss me. It starts as a formal kiss, but then VIRGINIA, shockingly direct, pushes her lips against VANESSA. VIRGINIA holds her mouth a moment. When they part, VANESSA is overwhelmed, blushing at the power of VIRGINIA'S need.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Did you think I was better? Say something, Nessa. Didn't you think I seemed better? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Yes, Virginia. You seem better. VIRGINIA continues to look at her sister, pleadingly.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: You think... you think I may one day escape? There is a silence, the two women still eye to eye.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: One day. One.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Nessa... There's a short silence, broken by the sound of a car horn outside. .

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Come, Angelica. We must go. VANESSA and ANGELICA go out of the door. ANGELICA. turns back and waves.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: Good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Good-bye, little girl. NELLY, returning from outside, closes the door and gives VIRGINIA a look as she returns to the kitchen. VIRGINIA stands alone in the hall. LEONARD is standing at the end of the corridor, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys are already in the taxi. VANESSA, obviously upset, wordlessly ushers ANGELICA to get in. Then she gets in herself, and draws ANGELICA to her.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Here. On my knee. Stay close. VANESSA signals to the DRIVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS lets the outside door of CLARISSA'S apartment building close behind him. He stands a moment at the top of the steps, full of relief to have left. Then, gratefully, he goes on his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARISSA closes the door of the apartment and goes back into her living room, intending to resume her preparations for the party. But instead she stands, in the middle of the room, now bereft. She does not move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIRGINIA walks alone up the staircase. At the half-way landing there is a large window. VIRGINIA stops. Outside, she can see the happy family departing -- the three children chattering excitedly to VANESSA. Their car disappears. VIRGINIA watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A handsome, 19-year-old GIRL, lush and strong, in combat trousers and sweater comes along Tenth Street. She crackles with health like an Irish farm-girl. She bounds up the steps of CLARISSA'S apartment block and lets herself in with her key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl is CLARISSA'S daughter JULIA and now she is letting herself in to the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I know, I tried to get here earlier. I tried. Okay? Don't start. I know. It's just incredibly important. Because it's your party. CLARISSA turns from where she is standing.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Julia. How you've been doing?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I'm fine. CLARISSA has gone over to embrace her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Come here. What've you been doing? ‘ JULIA Well, studying, Mom. JULIA eases out of her mother's needy embrace, blithely to take off her backpack.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What should I do? Chairs?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Oh. Can you clear my desk? CLARISSA'S desk is covered in books which JULIA now clears by carrying them through to the bedroom. As she goes she calls back to her mother.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I bumped into Louis Waters.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: You did. Where?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: In the street. They're all here aren't they? The ghosts. The ghosts are assembling for the party. He's weird. JULIA on her way through sees her mother's face.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You mean you can't see that? You can't see Louis Waters is weird?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I can see that he's sad.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: All your friends are sad. JULIA expects CLARISSA to laugh, but then stops, books in hand, seeing how preoccupied her mother is.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You've been crying. What's happening? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: All it is: I looked around this room. I thought, I'm giving a party. All I want to do is just give a party.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: And? CLARISSA shakes her head, angry with herself.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I know why he does it! He does it deliberately!

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Who? Is this Richard?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Of course! JULIA smiles to herself, as if she's used to it.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: He looks at me. He did it this morning. He gave me that look.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What look?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Oh, to say: ‘You're trivial, your life is so trivial. Daily stuff, schedules. Parties. Details.' CLARISSA turns, suddenly protesting.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: That's what he means by it. That's what he's saying!

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Mom, it only matters if you think it's true. CLARISSA looks at her, taken aback by what JULIA has said. They both become quiet now.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Well? Do you? Tell me. There's a silence. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: When I'm with him, then, yes, I'm living. That's what I feel. And when I'm not, yes, things seem kind of silly. JULIA walks away to the bedroom, struck by her mother's tactlessness.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I don't mean with you. Never with you. But the rest of it.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Sally?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: The rest of it. False comfort. CLARISSA has followed JULIA into the bedroom and now they lie down, side by side, on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: If you say to me: when was I happiest?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Mom...

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Tell me the moment you were happiest...

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I know. It was years ago.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: All you're saying is, you were once young. CLARISSA smiles at JULIA'S remark. But JULIA knows it is still not resolved.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I remember one morning. Getting up at dawn. There was such a sense of possibility. We were going to do everything. Do you know that feeling? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JULIA nods, finally allowing what her mother is saying.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I remember thinking: 'This is the beginning of happiness.' That's what I thought. 'So this is the feeling. This is where it starts. And of course there'll always be more.' It never occurred to me: it wasn't the beginning. It was happiness. It was the moment, right then. There is a silence. JULIA looks thoughtfully at her mother. Then the DOOR BUZZER sounds. CLARISSA goes to the intercom, and a VOICE calls through: "Caterers."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beef being dumped down into a frying pan filled with onions and being vigorously stirred, a pan of beef bones bubbling next to it. NELLY and LOTTIE working together in the well-lit kitchen, a whole range of vegetables laid out on the chopping boards for supper. NELLY, who misses nothing, looks up from her cooking at the sound of someone coming downstairs. The kitchen door is open and gives onto the stairway. A figure moves quickly by, but NELLY sees. VIRGINIA is heading out in a long coat. LOTTIE has also looked up, the two of them noting VIRGINIA'S departure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIRGINIA in her coat hurrying out, trying to make sure she is not noticed. She moves quickly through the garden. In the distance, LEONARD is digging at the edge of the garden. But his back is turned and he does not notice her. She hastens towards the gate, and out into the road outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a summer evening, darkening a little, as VIRGINIA comes to the Victorian portico of Richmond station. Two MEN, returning from London, pass, and she catches a whiff of their conversation: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MEN
dialogues.text: I told him that's what he had to do and if he didn't like it that was his business. VIRGINIA passes them, trying not to be noticed, going into the hall, a fine canopied space of glass and arched ironwork. She goes to the ticket booth.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: I need a ticket to London, please.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Yes, madam. A single or a return?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a presentiment of what will happen again in 18 years’ time LEONARD WOOLF comes in from the garden. It's a different house and a different hallway, but the action is the same. LEONARD sits to put on his slippers, hearing the sounds of the house. Then, as if noticing something, frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEONARD appears at the kitchen door. NELLY is standing behind her stew.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Ah, Nelly, good evening. I was wondering if you'd seen Mrs. Woolf.

dialogues.speaker: NELLY
dialogues.text: I thought you knew, sir. Mrs. Woolf has gone out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEONARD WOOLF, in blind panic, fleeing the house, not in a coat, just out into the garden, and away off down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A middle-aged man, LEONARD WOOLF, running in his slippers, vest and corduroy jacket, charging down the hill towards the town.  78 71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEONARD comes down the steps towards the railway platform. He sees VIRGINIA sitting rather conspicuously by herself on a bench at the end of the platform. A train has just gone, so there is not another traveler in sight. The railway line stretches away to London, empty and quiet. VIRGINIA is trying not to be self-conscious, but she is tense. She turns.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Ah Mr. Woolf, what an unexpected pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: And perhaps you could tell me exactly what you think you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: What I was doing? Why --

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: I went to look for you and you weren't there. LEONARD moves towards her. VIRGINIA stays calm, resisting his panic.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: You were working in the garden. I didn't wish to disturb you.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: You disturb me when you disappear.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: I didn't disappear. I went for a walk.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: A walk? Is that all? VIRGINIA doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Is that all? Just a walk? They have neither of them moved. LEONARD is firm now.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Virginia, Nelly is cooking dinner. She has already had a difficult day. We must go home. We must eat Nelly's dinner. It is our obligation to eat Nelly's dinner. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: There is no such obligation! No such obligation exists.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Virginia, you have an obligation to your own sanity.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: And what is your role, Leonard? My husband? Or my prison guard? LEONARD is shocked by her fierceness. He tries to soften his tone, but VIRGINIA flares up as soon as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Virginia...

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: I have endured this custody. I have endured this imprisonment. I am attended by doctors. Everywhere I am attended by doctors who inform me of my own interests.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: They know your interests.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: They do not! They do not speak for my interests! How dare they presume? Let us imagine a life in which women are the doctors, and the men sit alone all day in shuttered rooms in the suburbs. Let us imagine that! LEONARD shifts, but is still determined not to back down. Behind him the odd PASSENGER is beginning to arrive to wait for London train.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Virginia, it is hard... I can see it must be hard for a woman... for a woman of your...

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Of what? A woman of my what exactly?

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: A woman of your gifts... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Oh I see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... of your... of your talents... to accept that she is not always the best judge of her own condition.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: No? Who, then, is a better judge? Bring this judge to Platform One. Let me meet them. VIRGINIA is looking at him defiantly.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: You have a history...

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Oh yes...

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: You came to Richmond with a history of confinement. Fits. Blackouts. Moods. Hearing voices. We brought you here to escape the irrevocable damage you intended to yourself. Twice you have tried to take your life by your own hand. VIRGINIA is watching him closely now, attending every word, still not giving way.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: I live daily with that threat. VIRGINIA looks at him, refusing to answer.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: I set up the press, we set up the printing press...

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Not for itself. Not purely as a thing in itself. But that you might find a ready occupation, a ready source of absorption and of remedy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Like needlework? VIRGINIA has suddenly shouted. LEONARD for a moment loses his temper.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: It was done for you! It was done for your betterment! It was done out of love. If I did not know you better I would call this ingratitude.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: I am ungrateful? You call me ungrateful? VIRGINIA looks at him, accusing, shaking.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: My life has been stolen from me. I am living in a town I have no wish to live in. I am living a life I have no wish to live. And I am asking how this has occurred. VIRGINIA nods, sure of her point. There are now several PASSENGERS on the long London platform, but VIRGINIA and LEONARD ignore them completely.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: It is time for us to move back to London. I miss London. I miss London life.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: This is not you speaking, Virginia. This is an aspect of your illness.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: It is me. It is my voice. It is mine and mine alone.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: It is not your voice. It is only a voice you hear.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: It is not! It is mine! I am dying in this town! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: VIRGINIA is inflamed, passionate, almost mad. LEONARD looks at her, trying to keep calm.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: If you were clear... if you were thinking clearly, you would remember: it was London which brought you low.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: If I were thinking clearly?

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: We brought you to Richmond to give you peace. VIRGINIA takes a moment to summon all her lucidity.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: If I were thinking clearly? If I were thinking clearly, Leonard, I would tell you that I wrestle alone in the dark, and that only I can know, only I can understand my own condition. You live with the threat, you tell me. You live with the threat of my extinction. There is silence. She is trembling, white.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Leonard, I live with it too. Now it is LEONARD who cannot answer.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: This is my right. This is the right of every human being. I choose not the suffocating anesthetic of the suburbs, but the violent jolt of the capital. That is my choice. The meanest patient, yes even the very lowest, is allowed some say in the matter of her own prescription. Thereby she defines her humanity. VIRGINIA is calm now, certain. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: I wish for your sake, Leonard, that I could be happy in this quietness. But if it is a choice between Richmond and death, I choose death. There are now tears in LEONARD'S eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Very well. London, then. We shall go back to London. LEONARD bows his head, overwhelmed by the defeat of his strategy. There is a silence. VIRGINIA watches, full of feeling for him. Then, at the opposite platform the train from London arrives. From its doors, phalanxes of COMMUTERS in dark coats and hats get down onto the platform and head for the exit. LEONARD looks up, wiping away his tears.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: You must be hungry. I ama little hungry myself. VIRGINIA smiles. They look at each other, the issue at last resolved between them.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Come along. VIRGINIA and LEONARD get up and walk together along the deserted platform, both shaken by the encounter. After a moment, VIRGINIA takes his arm. They walk a while, arm in arm, merging into the crowd of COMMUTERS. Then VIRGINIA speaks, almost as an afterthought.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: You do not find peace by avoiding life, Leonard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAURA'S car draws up outside MRS. LATCH'S house. RICHIE has plainly heard her arrive, for when she looks to the window, RICHIE is already banging his hands against it and screaming:

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Mommy! Mommy! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAURA looks, fearful. Then she gets out of the car. Along the neat suburban street, sprinklers play across lawns, catching the evening light like fountains. RICHIE comes running from the house towards his mother with a triumphant cry of...

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: It's Mommy! MRS. LATCH follows.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LATCH
dialogues.text: Why, hello, Laura.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh, Mrs. Latch. I'm sorry I'm late. LAURA picks RICHIE up and he buries his face in her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh, now. Hey. Hey. Hey there, bug. What's wrong? What's wrong? MRS. LATCH smiles reassuringly.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LATCH
dialogues.text: He's fine. He's been fine. He's just pleased to see you.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Come on, it wasn't that bad. It wasn't that bad, was it? RICHIE has buried himself in LAURA. MRS. LATCH nods at LAURA'S hair.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LATCH
dialogues.text: You got it cut, then?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Yes. No problem.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LATCH
dialogues.text: It looks great.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Thank you. They didn't have to do very much. LAURA smiles, embarrassed at the lie. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LATCH
dialogues.text: We had a fine time together.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Thank you. Very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them are driving side by side. LAURA has her eyes on the road. RICHIE is staring straight ahead, not looking at her. The car is moving noiselessly along suburban avenues. There is a long silence. They seem more like two adults than mother and child.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: So that wasn't too bad, was it? I wasn't gone long?

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: No, you weren't long.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That's right. At one point... I don't know... there was a moment when I thought I might be longer. But I changed my mind. RICHIE says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Honey, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Mommy, I love you. There is a moment's pause.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I love you too, baby. There is a thoughtful look on RICHIE'S face.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What's wrong? RICHIE looks at LAURA as if he knows where she has been.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What? But still RICHIE says nothing, just goes on looking. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Don't worry, honey. Everything's fine. We're going to have a wonderful party. We've made Daddy such a nice cake. RICHIE is still looking at her, watchful.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I love you, sweetheart. You're my guy. RICHIE is seen from LAURA'S POINT OF VIEW, his little face flushed for a moment with pleasure. The SOUND FADES, and there is a SLOW DISSOLVE THROUGH TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICHARD'S face seen from the exact SAME POINT OF VIEW. The child has become the man. RICHARD is sitting in the near dark, a gleam of light catching the sweat on his forehead. He has not moved from his chair, nor has he dressed. He sits thinking back to the scene in the car. LAURA'S voice is heard in RICHARD'S head.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I love you, sweetheart. You're my guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARISSA gets out of a hired car in the afternoon light, and heads into the doorway of the triangle building. She gets quickly into the elevator. The elevator ascends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beside RICHARD, a photograph of his mother, LAURA, on her wedding day, eyes down. RICHARD looks at it, the extreme sweat of illness running down his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARISSA, in a repeat of the morning's progress, comes to the door of RICHARD'S apartment and rings the bell to warn him of her presence. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Richard, Richard, it's me. I'm early. I know. She puts her key in the lock and opens the door. The blinds have been pulled up and the curtains parted for the first time. In full light at last, it looks like the apartment of a madman -- piles of cardboard boxes, a filthy bathtub, books flung everywhere. CLARISSA moves forward in astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Richard! What the hell's going on?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? You're early. RICHARD is pushing furniture to the side. He looks like an exalted scarecrow, his hair plastered to his skull. He's high as a kite, and still dressed in his bathrobe and pajamas. Immediately behind him, he has opened the window wide. CLARISSA looks in horror.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Richard, what are you doing? What's going on? RICHARD looks at her from across the room, his eyes gleaming.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Clarissa, I had this wonderful idea. I needed some light. I needed to let in some light. RICHARD moves toward the window.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Richard, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I had this fantastic notion. I took the Xanax and the Ritalin together. It had never occurred to me.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Richard! RICHARD screams at her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Don't come near me! CLARISSA stops. RICHARD scrambles painfully to the windowsill and lifts one leg over the sill, so that he is perched, bony, weightless, with the other foot still on the apartment floor. CLARISSA stands, trying to be caln.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: It seemed to me I needed to let in some light. What do you think? I cleared away all the windows.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: All right, do me one favor, Richard, do me one simple favor...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I don't think I can make it to the party, Clarissa. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: You don't have to go to the party. You don't have to go to the ceremony. RICHARD'S face darkens. CLARISSA shouts in desperation.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: You don't have to do anything, Richard! You can do what you like!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: But I have to face the hours, don't I? The hours after the party. And the hours after that.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: You have good days still, Richard. You know you do.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Not really. It's kind of you to say so, but it isn't true. CLARISSA is stopped dead, full of fear at her next question.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Are they here, Richard? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: The voices?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Oh, the voices are always here.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: But is it the voices you're hearing now?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No, Mrs. Dalloway. It's you. CLARISSA looks at him, terrified now.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I've stayed alive for you. RICHARD looks at her pleadingly.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: But now you have to let me go. CLARISSA looks at him, shocked by what he has said. But again as she moves toward him, he cuts her off.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Richard...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Tell me a story, all right?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: What about?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Tell me a story from your day. CLARISSA stops, fearing this is their last moment together.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I got up...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yes? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: And... I went out to get flowers -- just like Mrs. Dalloway -- in the book, do you know?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: -- it was a beautiful morning.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Was it?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Yes. It was beautiful. It was so fresh. CLARISSA shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Fresh, was it?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Like a morning on the beach?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Like that?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Fresh like when you and I were young? There is a silence. CLARISSA doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Like the morning you walked out of that old house and you were eighteen, and maybe I was nineteen.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I was nineteen years old and I'd never seen anything so beautiful. You, coming out of a glass door in the early morning, still sleepy. Isn't it strange?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes it's strange.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: The most ordinary morning in anybody's life. RICHARD shakes his head slightly.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Clarissa, I'm afraid I can't make the party.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: The party doesn't matter. Give me your hand. CLARISSA reaches out to him.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You've been so good to me, Mrs. Dalloway.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Richard...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I love you. CLARISSA stops, taken aback as he says it.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I don't think two people could have been happier than we've been. There is a moment's silence. Then RICHARD inches forward, slides gently off the sill, and falls. CLARISSA screams.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. No sound. Seen FROM BELOW, RICHARD'S body floating slowly down from the fifth floor in the air.  86 87 88 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARISSA looks at the empty window. Then she steps back away from the window, just staring, making no noise. She takes one step back and then another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICHARD'S body lands against the concrete, SMASHING a BEER BOTTLE as it does. The corpse bounces, then settles, face down, his robe up over his face. Silence again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cake, now bright with lit candles on the dining room table. A great effort has been made for DAN'S birthday and the front room is bright with light and decoration. DAN blows out his-candles in one long go. RICHIE and LAURA watch from their seats at the table.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE AND LAURA
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday! Happy Birthday, Dan! They all laugh.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: This is perfect. This is just perfect.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Do you think so? Do you really think so?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Why sure. You must have been working all day.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Well we were. Weren't we, bug? That's what we were doing. Working all day.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: This is just fantastic. It's what I've always wanted. LAURA is doing well as the good wife, sharing her husband's delight in the cake. RICHIE is watching, with a serious expression. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh, Dan...

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: One day I'll tell you, Richie. I'll tell you how it all happened...

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Don't. LAURA seems embarrassed. DAN looks up at her, quiet but serious.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I want to. I want to tell him the story. LAURA is silent, giving permission, but ill at ease. DAN looks at RICHIE, full of pleasure at picking his way exactly through his story.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: What happened: When I was at war -~ at war I found myself thinking -- and I remembered that there was this girl that I'd seen -- I'd never met her -- at high school -- this strange, fragile-looking girl called Laura McGrath. Yeah. And she was shy. And she was interesting. And -- your mother won't mind me telling you this, Richie -- she was the kind of girl you see sitting mostly on her own. RICHIE is listening intently. The three of them are intent 'round the table.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Richie, I'll tell you: Sometimes when I was in the South Pacific, the fact is, I used to think of this girl...

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Dan...

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I thought of bringing her to a house -- a life -- well, pretty like this. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And it was the thought of the happiness... the thought of this woman... the thought of this life... that is what kept me going. There is silence. DAN is looking at LAURA.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I had an idea of our happiness. RICHIE watches, aware of the awful sadness between them.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Did you make a wish? DAN has taken one of the yellow roses from the cake, and, unaware, has been rolling it between his fingers, back and forth, back and forth. He is alone with his thoughts for a few moments, then he turns and looks blankly at LAURA. Then he nods.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Yes, I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARISSA is seen through the glass panel in a door waiting at the morgue. She is standing in distress, shaken by the events of the afternoon. Then SALLY arrives at the door, led into the morgue by an ORDERLY. She stops a moment to look through the door. Now, full of feeling, she opens the door to join CLARISSA. CLARISSA looks across.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the drawing room, there are two pools of light from standard lamps. On opposite sides of the room LEONARD and VIRGINIA are sitting, a kind of truce between them after the events of the afternoon. They are both reading. VIRGINIA'S book is in her hand. She still has the London rail ticket, which she is using as a bookmark. She fingers the ticket, turning it over. After a few moments LEONARD looks up, as if something has occurred to him from a previous conversation.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Why does someone have to die? VIRGINIA looks up and frowns. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Leonard?

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: In your book?

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: You said someone has to die. Why? LEONARD catches just a trace of VIRGINIA'S reaction.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Is that a stupid question?

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: I imagine my question is stupid.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Well? VIRGINIA gives it thought before answering.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Someone has to die in order that the rest of us should value life more. LEONARD looks at her, the two of them serious now.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: It's contrast.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: And who will die?

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: It's a secret.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Tell me. VIRGINIA pauses, then gives him the gift of an answer.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: The poet will die. The visionary.  91 92 93 94 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICHIE, the poet, the visionary, lying in the bed ina little room painted with stars. It is decorated with pictures of rockets and imaginary astronauts. His face is alert on the pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Browns' house seen from the road. It's dark. Just one pool of light is thrown onto their drive by a side- window. The street at peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICHIE is lying awake listening to the sound of his father in the next room calling to LAURA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAURA is sitting, her head in her hands, on the closed toilet seat. She is in white pajamas, bent down in an attitude of abject despair, umable to move. After a few moments, DAN calls through from the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (0.S8.)
dialogues.text: What are you doing? LAURA looks up. She has taken her make-up off and it is plain she has been crying.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm brushing my teeth.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are you coming to bed?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes. In a minute.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Come to bed, Laura Brown. But LAURA doesn't move, just turns away, trapped.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I ran into Ray, he says Kitty's had to go to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That's right. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: o DAN (0.S.) Nothing serious, he said. Justa checkup.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm terrified. wh DAN (0.S.) y? LAURA speaks quietly, not loud enough for DAN to hear.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh, the idea she could disappear. DAN has not heard anything.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Perhaps you could go see her in the morning, honey.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I was going to. I was going to stop by. Co There is another short silence. LAURA is unable to mov

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I've had a wonderful day and I have you to thank. LAURA looks away, in despair now.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Come to bed, honey.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm coming. But still LAURA stands, not moving. After a while, DAN speaks again.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So. Are you coming?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes. In the distance, you can hear a DOG BARKING. LAURA gets up and reaches for the pull-light over the mirror. The ane bathroom goes dark. She takes the steps which bring h co to the door which leads to the door which leads to the bedroom. LAURA stands in the door, the only light falling on her face.  95 96 91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIRGINIA is now sitting in her favorite chair with a writing board across her lap, notebook in hand. The light pools around her. She is not writing, just thinking. LEONARD appears in the doorway opposite. He says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: What? What? LEONARD smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: I was hoping you were going to bed.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: I am. I am going to bed. They look at each other, their eyes full of love and humor.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: What then?

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: All else is clear. The outline of the story is planned. Now one thing only. VIRGINIA shakes her head very slightly, still in the chair.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Mrs. Dalloway's destiny must be resolved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARISSA is in the kitchen with SALLY and JULIA. Every surface is taken up with food for the party which never happened. CLARISSA has the crab dish in her hand and is emptying it sadly into the bin. She is still in the coat she was wearing all afternoon. As she dumps the wasted food, she hears a RING at the DOOR. CLARISSA goes to the apartment door and opens it. LAURA BROWN is standing directly opposite. She is now in her early 80s, slightly stooped with steel-gray hair and parchment skin. She is wearing a dark, floral dress and coat. CLARISSA is taken aback for a moment. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: You're Laura Brown.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm Richard's mother.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Of course. CLARISSA reaches out her hand.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I'm Clarissa Vaughan. Come in. LAURA has a small bag which CLARISSA now lifts for her as she leads her into the apartment. At the end of the corridor SALLY is standing with JULIA behind her, but CLARISSA signals tactfully for them to hold off a moment, as she leads LAURA into the sitting room. Throughout the apartment, dinner tables have been set with white table cloths, and glasses. CLARISSA is alone with LAURA in the sitting room.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: My friend Sally's in the kitchen. And my daughter. LAURA just looks at her a moment, not answering.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: We were having a party. We were going to have a party.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I was lucky. I got the last plane from Toronto. In the kitchen, unheard, unseen, JULIA watches, then speaks quietly to SALLY.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: So that's the monster. LAURA has approached a table loaded with RICHARD'S books.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I hope I did the right thing. I found your number in his phone book.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes. He had it. But we didn't speak often. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAURA is looking at RICHARD'S picture. CLARISSA stands a moment, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It's a terrible thing, Miss Vaughan, to outlive your whole family.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Richard's father died...

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes. He died of cancer. Quite young. And Richard's sister is dead. LAURA looks at her a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Obviously you feel unworthy. It gives you feelings of unworthiness. You survive and they don't. CLARISSA waits a second before speaking.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Did you read the poems?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes. I read them. I also read the novel. You see, people say that the novel is difficult...

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I know...

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: They say that.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: I know...

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: He had me die in the novel. I know why he did that. It hurt, of course. I can't pretend it didn't hurt, but I know why he did it.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: You left Richie when he was a child?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I left both my children. I abandoned them. They say it's the worst thing a mother can do. Neither of them move. The room is silent now.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You have a daughter?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Yes. But I never met Julia's father.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You so wanted a child?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You're a very lucky woman. CLARISSA looks down. There's a

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: There are times when you don't belong and you think you're going to kill yourself. Once I went to a hotel. That night... later that night, I made a plan. Plan was, I would leave my family when my second child was born. And that's what I did. Got up one morning, made breakfast, went to the bus stop, got on a bus. I'd left a note. moment's silence.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I got a job in a library in Canada. It would be wonderful to say you regretted it. It would be easy. But what does it mean? What does it mean to regret when you have no choice? It's what you can bear. There it is. No one is going to forgive me. LAURA looks at CLARISSA, steady, unapologetic.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It was death. I chose life.  97 98 99 95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARISSA comes out of the sitting room down the hall of the apartment and quietly goes into their bedroom, still wearing her dark coat. SALLY is in the kitchen with JULIA and now look up at the sight of CLARISSA. She gets up and follows CLARISSA into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SALLY comes into the room to find CLARISSA sitting on the side of the bed in her coat. The two women look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: You need to take your coat off. SALLY comes round and gestures to CLARISSA to stand up. SALLY puts her hands on CLARISSA'S shoulders to help her take off the coat. As she does, CLARISSA turns and looks at SALLY, the two of them overcome. The two women look warmly at each other, then they kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAURA is unpacking her suitcase on the bed in Julia's room. It has only a few things which she has hurriedly put in for the trip. She looks frail and alone. There is a KNOCK on the door and JULIA comes in with a cup and saucer.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I thought you might like a cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That's very kind, dear. I feel I'm stealing your room. JULIA has put the tea down beside the bed.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: We put the food away, so... if you're hungry in the night, just help yourself.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Well, I will. You have somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Yes. The sofa. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Instinctively JULIA moves towards her and puts her arms round her. The 18-year-old and the 80-year-old embrace. LAURA stands a moment, astonished at her warmth. Then JULIA moves away.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Good night, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIRGINIA lies in bed, making no effort to sleep, but lying by moonlight in her bed, her eyes open, white like a ghost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corridor of the apartment. Everyone else has gone to bed. CLARISSA, in her white pajamas, is in the kitchen turning off the lights one by one. As she turns off the last one in the kitchen, she comes into the corridor, and begins the same process. She looks round briefly at her own home: comfortable, solid, complete. At last she seems at peace. As she turns out the lights in the corridor, the voice of VIRGINIA WOOLF is heard.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Leonard, to look life in the face, always to look life in the face, and to know what it is, to love it for what it is. At last to know it. To love it for what it is. And then to put it away. CLARISSA turns out the last light and the corridor is darkened. She turns and goes into her room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIRGINIA WOOLF walks calmly once more into the river.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Leonard, always the years between us, always the years, always the love. Always the hours. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: VIRGINIA stands a moment, up to her neck in the water, about to plunge herself under. The sun plays on the water. FADE OUT.
